source_scope.region_label: North Alabama: Athens–Decatur–Hartselle–Priceville and surrounding counties (Limestone, Morgan, nearby)
source_scope.notes: Selection focuses on practical, non-alarmist, fact-first stories with clear local impact (jobs, infrastructure, city/county actions, community events). Routine crime blotters and fear-based coverage are excluded.

articles.title: Athens opens a state-supported Career Center on Athens State’s campus
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- A new Athens Career Center has opened on the Athens State University campus as a full-service extension of Alabama’s workforce services.
- The center is positioned to help both job seekers and employers with hiring, placement, and training support.

## Key facts
- The Athens Career Center reopen/launch was marked by a ribbon-cutting involving local, state, and university leadership.
- Services listed include resume help, job placement, education/vocational training assistance, and employer services like pre-screening.
- Location: Chasteen Hall on Athens State’s campus (suite location provided in the article).

## Why it matters
- Consolidates “first-step” employment services locally, which can reduce friction for hiring and job transitions in Limestone County.
- Adds another workforce-development layer alongside regional growth and employer demand.

## What to watch next
- Whether the center publishes recurring hiring events, training schedules, or employer-partner announcements.
- Early indicators of usage (appointments, hiring outcomes, employer participation) once the center has been operating for a few months.

articles.title: Food City project in Athens gets a $300K grant for traffic and drainage upgrades
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- A state Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) award is tied to road and drainage upgrades needed for a new Food City site and nearby retail development.
- The project is framed as both a traffic-access fix and an economic-development enablement step.

## Key facts
- Grant amount: $300,000 (CDBG), administered in Alabama by ADECA.
- Work described: widening, deceleration/turn lanes, and drainage improvements near West Elm Street and Lucas Ferry Road.
- The article cites expectations of ~100 new jobs and a 57,000 sq. ft. store planned to open next spring, with additional private investment details.

## Why it matters
- This is the type of “invisible” infrastructure work (turn lanes/drainage) that often determines whether large retail projects move smoothly or create long-term traffic headaches.
- The public/private pairing is a common growth model: targeted roadway upgrades unlock larger private buildouts.

## What to watch next
- Timeline for the intersection work and whether it phases around peak traffic times.
- Any follow-on retail announcements tied to the same development footprint.

articles.title: Festival of the Cranes returns Jan 9–11 with events across Decatur venues

geo.place_name: Decatur and Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge (Limestone/Morgan/Madison)

articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- The Festival of the Cranes runs January 9–11, centered around Wheeler National Wildlife Refuge and multiple Decatur venues.
- The weekend blends wildlife viewing with talks, workshops, and family activities.

## Key facts
- The story notes the refuge’s winter crane presence (including large numbers of sandhill cranes and a small number of whooping cranes) and highlights observation opportunities.
- Venues listed include the Princess Theatre, Cook Museum of Natural Science, the Decatur Public Library, and the Alabama Center for the Arts.
- The observation building address is provided in the article for visitors who want indoor viewing.

## Why it matters
- Big seasonal draw that reliably boosts weekend foot traffic for nearby cultural sites and local businesses.
- Practical “low-barrier” nature programming: even non-birders can participate without specialized gear.

## What to watch next
- Weather impacts on outdoor viewing and any schedule adjustments announced by organizers.
- Spillover programming (additional workshops, extended hours, or added sessions) if attendance is strong.

articles.title: Decatur completes renovation of the Flying Dragon Disc Golf Course at Jack Allen
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- Decatur finished renovations to the Flying Dragon Disc Golf Course at the Jack Allen Recreation Complex.
- The work is described as improving safety, playability, and navigation.

## Key facts
- Location: Jack Allen Recreation Complex (Flying Dragon Disc Golf Course).
- The city frames the renovation around user experience: easier wayfinding and safer play.
- The announcement is posted as an official city update.

## Why it matters
- Low-cost, high-usage recreation upgrades can significantly increase park utilization and community programming options.
- Clear navigation and safety improvements reduce “drop-off” for new players and families.

## What to watch next
- Any follow-up community events (clinic days, league play, tournaments) that leverage the renovated course.
- Whether similar upgrades appear on the city’s parks/recreation pipeline for 2026.

articles.title: Point Mallard Golf Course to close Jan 19 for irrigation and course improvements
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- Point Mallard Golf Course will temporarily close starting January 19, 2026 to complete course and irrigation improvements.
- The city expects roughly a three-month construction window, weather permitting.

## Key facts
- Closure start: Monday, January 19, 2026.
- Timeline: about three months, with a target of reopening in April; some holes may reopen on a limited basis as work progresses.
- The city cites a $1.5M irrigation upgrade approved by the City Council and funded through a $35.2M bond issue approved in October.

## Why it matters
- Irrigation is “infrastructure under the grass” — upgrades can materially improve course conditions and reduce future maintenance disruptions.
- The city explicitly links the work to positioning the facility for competitive and tournament play.

## What to watch next
- If the city publishes a phased reopening map (which holes reopen first) and any pricing/promotional changes after reopening.
- Any additional Point Mallard Park Complex improvements tied to the same bond funding cycle.

articles.title: Decatur backs statewide push to update Alabama’s online sales tax distribution system
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- Decatur City Council voted to support a statewide effort aimed at changing Alabama’s Simplified Sellers Use Tax (SSUT) system.
- The city did not join the lawsuit referenced, but formally endorsed the goal of a more “fair” distribution approach.

## Key facts
- The city’s action followed a briefing from its CFO explaining how SSUT impacts Decatur revenue as online shopping grows.
- The city statement argues the current formula can shift local tax dollars away from the community where purchases are delivered/used.
- The decision is framed around revenue stability for local services rather than a new local tax.

## Why it matters
- Small percentage changes in sales-tax distribution can be a meaningful budget line item for cities — especially as retail continues shifting online.
- Residents typically feel this indirectly through service levels, maintenance schedules, and long-range planning capacity.

## What to watch next
- Whether the statewide lawsuit or legislative action produces a timeline for reform, and what implementation would look like for cities.
- Any follow-up city finance briefings that quantify Decatur’s estimated impact under alternative formulas.

articles.title: Decatur approves ‘Option B’ plan to move the Modaus Road Sportsplex forward
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- Decatur City Council unanimously approved an updated “Option B” plan for the Modaus Road Sportsplex.
- The city frames the redesign as a path to balance cost, function, and long-term use after earlier project pauses.

## Key facts
- The article cites the construction pause in September 2024 for reassessment after cost realities outpaced an original budget.
- The city states that roughly $15M has already been invested in site prep, utilities, and core construction.
- Approval of Option B is positioned as the step that allows forward momentum on a revised build strategy.

## Why it matters
- Large recreation builds are multi-year commitments; design resets can be expensive, but finishing with a usable footprint can protect prior sunk costs.
- Community sports facilities affect tournament traffic, local hotel/restaurant spend, and youth program capacity.

## What to watch next
- Updated construction timeline, revised scope details, and whether the city publishes a phased opening plan.
- Any new funding/bond details or vendor contracts tied specifically to the Option B configuration.

articles.title: Hartselle reminds businesses: annual licenses are due Jan 1 and delinquent Feb 1
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- The City of Hartselle posted a January reminder for annual business (privilege) license renewals.
- Alcohol license renewals and mobile food unit renewals/inspections are also called out as January items.

## Key facts
- Renewals are due January 1 each year; licenses become delinquent as of February 1.
- The city states that every business operating within city limits must obtain a license to legally conduct business.
- Mobile food unit permits require scheduling an inspection prior to renewal, and the city provides contact channels for forms and questions.

## Why it matters
- Straightforward compliance item that can prevent avoidable penalties or administrative delays.
- Useful for small operators (especially mobile vendors) who can miss inspection scheduling windows.

## What to watch next
- Whether the city updates fee schedules, online renewal options, or adds business-office hours during peak renewal season.
- Any ARC/council meeting notices related to alcohol license applications and renewals.

articles.title: ALDOT: I-65 patching between Hartselle and Priceville, with resurfacing continuing into 2026
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- ALDOT advised motorists to expect daytime patching and delays on I-65 between Hartselle and Priceville.
- The announcement also contextualizes the work as part of a broader resurfacing project spanning Cullman, Morgan, and Limestone counties.

## Key facts
- Work zone described: between Exit 328 (SR-36 in Hartselle) and Exit 334 (SR-67 in Priceville).
- Work hours given: 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. (weather permitting) with single-lane closures; crews planned to work southbound first, then northbound.
- ALDOT notes a second phase of resurfacing (SR-36 in Hartselle to north of the Tennessee River in Limestone County) planned to begin when weather permits in 2026.

## Why it matters
- For commuters and freight, short-term lane closures are disruptive, but patching before deeper winter deterioration can reduce pothole-related slowdowns later.
- The corridor is a primary north-south route for Morgan/Limestone access to Huntsville and beyond, so reliability affects regional travel time and logistics.

## What to watch next
- Start-of-2026 resurfacing updates (exact dates, nightly closure patterns) once temperatures support paving.
- Any posted detour guidance or ALGO traffic alerts during peak travel days.

articles.title: Limestone County Commission (Jan 5): agenda highlights include leases, service contracts, and budget actions
articles.body_markdown:
## Summary
- Limestone County posted agenda materials for its January 5 Commission meeting in Athens.
- Items span routine governance: property/lease decisions, service agreements, and budget-related approvals.

## Key facts
- Meeting time/location shown: 9:00 a.m., Commission Chambers, 100 South Clinton Street, Athens.
- The agenda materials include a work session and a commission meeting packet.
- Agenda topics include multiple approvals across departments (examples include property/lease actions, inter-agency service agreements, and budget revisions).

## Why it matters
- County meeting packets are where “small” operational approvals accumulate into real service delivery (roads, senior services, admin capacity).
- Useful for residents who want to track spending, contracts, and county priorities without noise.

## What to watch next
- The meeting video links (work session + commission meeting) for final votes and any amendments to agenda items.
- Upcoming agenda postings to see which items become recurring (contracts renewed annually, leases, standing service agreements).
